name: lobelia-puberula
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern and south central United States
wildlife-value: Its flowers are attractive to hummingbirds, butterflies and other pollinators.Â  Bees are pollinators of this plant.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: This plant is frequently damaged by deer.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
flower-description: The Downy lobelia features irregularly shaped, .75 in. blue flowers with a white center. The upper lip has two lobes and the lower lip has three lobes. The flower spike is often one-sided. Blooms late summer to fall, August-October.
leaf-description: Downy lobelia has soft, alternate leaves, each 1 to 2 inches. The leaves generally have small irregularly spaced teeth. They may be hairy, particularly on the underside.
poison-symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, salivation, exhaustion and weakness, dilation of pupils, convulsions, and coma
poison-toxic-principle: Alkaloids lobelamine, lobeline, and others, plus a volatile oil
